For the description of the use cases below, it is assumed the zone " "``my-domain.org.`` was created previously." msgstr "" "ユースケースを開始する前に、ユーザーは DNS サービスの自分のプロジェクト下に " "DNS ゾーンを作成しておかなければいけません。この DNS ゾーンに A レコードと " "AAAA レコードが作成されます。以下のユースケースの説明では、ゾーン ``my-" "domain.org`` がすでに作成されているものとします。" msgid """Set the needed ``notification_drivers`` in ``[qos]`` section (``messaging`` " "is the default).""``[qos]`` セクションで必要な ``notification_drives`` を設定します " "(``messaging`` がデフォルトです)。""The port's ``dns_assignment`` attribute shows that its FQDN is ``my-vm.my-" "domain.org.`` in the Networking service internal DNS, which is the result of " "concatenating the port's ``dns_name`` with the value configured in the " "``dns_domain`` parameter in ``neutron.conf``, as explained previously." msgstr "" "ポートの ``dns_assignment`` 属性では、 Networking サービスの内部 DNS での " "FQDN が ``my-vm.my-domain.org`` であることが分かります。この FQDN は、ポート" "の ``dna_name`` と ``neutron.conf`` の ``dns_domain`` パラメーターに設定され" "た値を結合したものです。" msgid ""

commit_message:
Document env.d changes in install guide

This patch adds a note to the current install guide, informing readers
of the change to env.d that happened in commit
7b288eafbe3fe36424111244e92f5c7998cdd699. This is more for awareness
than any action that a deployer has to take.

Change-Id: I9e5325dbf1b77d87f31849de0fc46b13e643375e

commit_message:
Restore MySQL and Postgresql functional testing

The oslo.db opportunistic test fixtures were not being
used effectively and the MySQL / PG databases were not
being used.  This patch restores working patterns against
oslo.db.  Additionally, the migration level tests have also
been updated to make use of oslo.db provisioning functionality
and unused methods have been removed.

The current approach makes use of oslo.db provisioning constructs
directly, as well as some semi-private attribute access within
oslo.db enginefacade, in order to work around some issues
that have arisen in oslo.db's test_base.
A new release of oslo.db will provide
public API points to resolve pending issues, and to
allow neutron's use cases here which will
also be of general applicability to openstack projects.

Closes-bug: #1594898

Change-Id: Ie27cf174fa24c2f479af47335d9ae139fb7d159a

revisions:

In this patch, auto schedule router will be removed from sync_routers,
so that the reported bug can be fixed. And potential race can be avoid
accoridng to [1]

The result of patch will make the l3 agent can't get the router info
when the router is not bound to the l3 agent. And router in agent will
be removed during the agent processing. This makes sense, since, in
neutron server, the router is not tied to the agent. For DVR, if there
are service port in the agent host, the router info will still be

(cherry picked from commit 64726983f2161b32e516f3f12007e5f5a3d57e50)

commit_message:
Not auto schedule router when sync routers from agent

In this patch, auto schedule router will be removed from sync_routers,
so that the reported bug can be fixed. And potential race can be avoid
accoridng to [1]

The result of patch will make the l3 agent can't get the router info
when the router is not bound to the l3 agent. And router in agent will
be removed during the agent processing. This makes sense, since, in
neutron server, the router is not tied to the agent. For DVR, if there
are service port in the agent host, the router info will still be
returned to l3 agent.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/317949/

Change-Id: Id0a8cf7537fefd626df06064f915d2de7c1680c6
Co-Authored-By: John Schwarz <jschwarz@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1593653
(cherry picked from commit 64726983f2161b32e516f3f12007e5f5a3d57e50)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/68/340868/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Update kuryr developer readme

Installation should mention getting the source code step
before using Prerequisites step which uses requirements.txt

commit_message:
Prints  '-' instead of 'None' when data is None

Client prints 'None' when data is None , and client also prints
'None' when data is a string 'None'. But string 'None' is  different
to None. To clarify the confusion, Client should print '-' instead of
'None' when data is None. Nova Client and Cinder Client has clarified
the confusion.

Change-Id: I6a8908fcb2df39d7f2c5fc4055cc41779d668d6c

commit_message:
Add Neutron security group plugin

The support for Neutron security groups did not
make it into Mitaka. This patch will add a new
plugin to monitor Neutron notifications related
to security group changes (group add, group
delete, group rule add).

Change-Id: I9d2b80e27eaf817cf561d28e067985fee7fe568d
Implements: blueprint neutron-security-group-plugin

added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2016 Hewlett-Packard Enterprise Development Company, L.P. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. from searchlight.common import resource_types from searchlight.elasticsearch.plugins import base from searchlight.elasticsearch.plugins.neutron import notification_handlers from searchlight.elasticsearch.plugins.neutron import serialize_security_group from searchlight.elasticsearch.plugins import openstack_clients class SecurityGroupIndex(base.IndexBase): NotificationHandlerCls = notification_handlers.SecurityGroupHandler @classmethod def get_document_type(self): return resource_types.NEUTRON_SECUITY_GROUP # @classmethod # def parent_plugin_type(cls): # return 'OS::Neutron::Net' # def get_parent_id_field(self): # return 'network_id' def get_mapping(self): string_not_analyzed = {'type': 'string', 'index': 'not_analyzed'} ordered_string = {'type': 'string', 'fields': {'raw': string_not_analyzed}} return { 'dynamic': False, 'properties': { 'security_group_rules': { 'type': 'nested', 'properties': { 'remote_group_id': ordered_string, 'direction': ordered_string, 'protocol': ordered_string, 'description': ordered_string, 'protocol': ordered_string, 'ethertype': ordered_string, 'remote_ip_prefix': ordered_string, 'port_range_max': ordered_string, 'port_range_min': ordered_string, 'security_group_id': ordered_string, 'tenant_id': ordered_string, 'id': ordered_string, }, }, 'id': string_not_analyzed, 'tenant_id': string_not_analyzed, 'name': ordered_string, 'description': ordered_string, }, "_meta": { "tenant_id": { "resource_type": resource_types.KEYSTONE_PROJECT }, } } @property def facets_with_options(self): return ('direction', 'ethertype') @property def facets_excluded(self): return {'tenant_id': True} def _get_rbac_field_filters(self, request_context): return [ {'term': {'tenant_id': request_context.owner}} ] def get_objects(self): """Generator that lists all security groups.""" neutron_client = openstack_clients.get_neutronclient() for group in neutron_client.list_security_groups()['security_groups']: yield group def serialize(self, sec_group): return serialize_security_group(sec_group)

commit_message:
Verify "needs:check_deprecation_status" for serial_console.py

This change verifies that the config options for serial console are
checked for their deprecation status according to:
    https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ConfigOptionsConsistency

The previously deprecated option "listen" gets removed.

bp centralize-config-options-newton

Change-Id: I000d676ee95d34d43530c2ce2e4d1b3c01dab063
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/80/338780/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
[cli-ref] clear work around for doc8 error

commit_message:
Change plugin version 'version' parameter to 'plugin-version'

Currently we have parameter 'version' for specifying plugin version
for creating node group templates and also for listing available
plugins. The problem is that this parameter is global parameter for
getting version of client. So, this patch fixes this confusion.

Change-Id: I89a670188c20e3b20b98b596a3efb8d5997c3214
Closes-bug: #1565775

commit_message:
Add an independent function to map segment to hosts

_add_segment_host_mapping_for_segment is to update SegmentHostMapping
when a new segment is created. Currently, this function is for agent.
For agentless topology, there is no agent to get the collection of
hosts. There are other ways to get the collection of hosts, which
should be mapped to the newly created segment.
This patch refactors fucntion _add_segment_host_mapping_for_segment,
and adds an independent function map_segment_to_hosts. So that the
agentless topology can use this function to update SegmentHostMapping
when a new segment is created.

Change-Id: If3cc33acc6a6395d0e67c8a74a770fc93e3702e5
Partially-Implements: blueprint routed-networks

commit_message:
VMware: Refactor the formatting instance metadata

Use a list of tuple instead of string format to join the instance
metadata in vmops _get_instance_metadata(), so that there would be
good correspondence between key and value.

Change-Id: I8c2f6e7199d97b77526a9ffefe5ad743c582dc1c

commit_message:
Add strict Boolean checking for volume manage

There is no strict boolean checking for the parameter
"bootable" of API /os-volume-manage, so that any invalid
boolean value can be specified.
This patch adds a strict checking for it to prevent
invalid value, and adds a test for this change as well.

Change-Id: I0d79a0bb173aaeeea0fe6d735213c70c109ccd69
Partial-Bug: #1594261
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/44/338244/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_manage_volume_with_invalid_bootable(self): """Test correct failure when invalid bool value is specified.""" body = {'volume': {'host': 'host_ok', 'ref': 'fake_ref', 'bootable': 'InvalidBool'}} res = self._get_resp_post(body) self.assertEqual(400, res.status_int) pass 'volume_type': fake.VOLUME_TYPE_ID, 'bootable': True}}

commit_message:
Implementation details to support trunk ports

This patch explains in details the changes needed for the OVS
agent to support vlan aware vms using two different models:
vlan interfaces and trunk bridge.

Change-Id: I74e0748869d1a2f27db95aafadf7d104cb1a1b3d
Partially-implements: blueprint vlan-aware-vms
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/17/318317/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Implementation VLAN Interfaces (Option A) ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Trunk port creation +++++++++++++++++++ When a trunk port is created, Neutron server will write the data of the new port into the database and no action will be performed by the L2 agent. A VM will be spawn passing to Nova the port-id of the trunk port. Nova will create the tap interface and will plug it into br-int or into the firewall bridge if using iptables firewall. In the external-ids of the port Nova will store the port ID of the trunk. The OVS agent detects that a new interface has been plugged. It gets the details of the new port after sending an RPC message (get_devices_details_list_and_failed_devices) to the Neutron server. The details returned will have a new boolean field "is_trunk", to specify that the port is a trunk port and a field "sub_ports" to return all the details of the subports associated to this trunk. If the trunk port is not associated to any subport, the L2 agent will install a drop flow to drop all the traffic, since no traffic is supposed to flow when no subport is defined. After that it will send a message notifying that the trunk port is up. Neutron will send back to Nova an event to signal that the wiring was successful. Subport creation ++++++++++++++++ When a subport is created or destroyed the L2 agent will get a notification. Currently the L2 agent is notified only when a port is deleted, we need to add a notification if a subport is created. When the OVS agent receives a port_create notification it will create a vlan interface on the VM tap using the VLAN id specified in the subport data. Let's see how the models differ when using the iptables firewall or the ovs native firewall. Iptables Firewall ''''''''''''''''' :: +----------------------------+ | VM | | eth0 eth0.100 | +-----+-----------------+----+ | | | | +---+---+ +---+---+ | qbr1 | | qbr2 | +---+---+ +---+---+ | | | | +-----+-----------------+----+ | port 1 port 2 | | | | br-int | +----------------------------+ Let's assume the subport is on network1 and uses segmentation ID 100. In the case of hybrid plugging the OVS agent will have to create the firewall bridge (qbr2), plug eth0.100 into it, connect it to br-int and set the subport ID in the external-ids of the port 2. *Inbound traffic* The untagged traffic will flow from eth0 through qbr1. Since there's no subport with no segmentation ID set, the untagged traffic will be dropped. For the traffic directed to port 2, the internal vlan ID of network1 will be stripped and vlan 100 will be pushed. The packet will then go through qbr2 where iptables rules will filter the traffic. *QUESTION* are firewall rules correctly applied by iptables when the traffic is tagged? *Outbound traffic* The untagged traffic will be dropped. Traffic tagged with vlan 100 will leave eth0.100, go through qbr2 where iptables rules will be applied and reach port 2. The OVS agent has installed a flow to strip vlan 100 and push the internal vlan of network1. OVS Firewall case ''''''''''''''''' :: +----------------------------+ | VM | | eth0 eth0.100 | +------+----------------+----+ | | | | | | +------+----------------+----+ | port 1 port 2 | | | | br-int | +----------------------------+ When a subport is created the OVS agent will create the vlan interface eth0.100 and plug it into br-int. *Outbound traffic* The untagged traffic will flow and reach port 1 where it will be dropped. Traffic tagged with vlan 100 will leave eth0.100 reach port2. The firewall driver has installed flows to apply security group rules to port 2. The OVS agent will install flow rules to strip VLAN 100 and push the VLAN used internally for network1. *Inbound traffic* For port 1 all the traffic is dropped. The traffic for port 2 will be filtered by the rules installed by the firewall. The internal vlan ID of network1 will be stripped and vlan 100 will be pushed. Subport deletion ++++++++++++++++ The OVS agent will get a notification that a subport needs to be deleted. The OVS agent will take care of removing the vlan interface, the firewall bridge if using iptables firewall and the port on br-int. Agent resync ++++++++++++ During resync the agent should check that all subports on br-int are still valid and delete the ones that are stale. The agent has no way of recognizing which port is a subport, it needs to get the device details from the server first and then perform the cleanup. Multiple subports that carry untagged traffic +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ WARNING!! With this model it's hard to support multiple subports that handle untagged traffic. Let's assume we have 2 subports, one connected to network1 and one to network2. They don't have the segmentation ID set, so they should carry untagged traffic. The agent should install flows for port 1 that tag the packets using the internal vlan id of network1. Since the packet should also reach network2, it should be copied and then tagged using the internal vlan id assigned to network2. Port 1 should have in the external ids the ids of both subports. Multiple port ids in the external ids are currently not supported. If we go for this option we should probably allow only one subport that carries untagged traffic. Implementation Trunk Bridge (Option C) ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ TODO(rossella_s)

commit_message:
update min tox version to 2.0

The commands used by constraints need at least tox 2.0. Update to
reflect reality, which should help with local running of constraints
targets.

Change-Id: I27348462a21daab479d76b24b48e3a4e017504cc

commit_message:
Fix gate keyerror on setuptools

setuptools 24.0.0 has bug and gate failing with that
as some old images still have version 24.0.0

http://logs.openstack.org/85/334285/2/gate/gate-tempest-dsvm-full/bc96067/logs/devstacklog.txt.gz#_2016-07-04_07_30_28_483

This patch fix the setuptools version to unblock the gate.

Change-Id: I7d50b6e8d3d18ae5a1f223ddbe017b2ebc363198

commit_message:
VLAN aware VMs

Adds support to use VLAN tagged frames from VM.

blueprint vlan-aware-vms
APIImpact

Change-Id: I015762abe197b91916374143410b1f182908909e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/12/94612/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== VLAN aware VMs ========================================== Launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/vlan-aware-vms This blueprint proposes how to incorporate VLAN aware VM:s into OpenStack. In this document a VLAN aware VM is a VM that sends and receives VLAN tagged frames over its vNIC. Pros are better scalability and more dynamic handling of Neutron networks connected to VMs. Problem description =================== Currently VLANs in VMs are not integrated with Neutron. A VM can only send untagged traffic. Use cases: * There are old legacy applications that are VLAN aware. These applications can more easily be adapted to OpenStack. * Some applications handle a large number (+100) of Neutron networks. It is more optimized to use VLANs instead of using one vNIC per network. * VLANs are more dynamic. It's usually less complex to add/remove a VLAN than to add/remove a vNIC, from a VM perspective. * Service VMs could use this to serve VMs from other Tenants. Proposed change =============== Proposal is to extend Neutron port so that it can act as a trunk or subport. The trunk port attaches to the VM and can send and receive tagged traffic. The trunk port will have subports attached to it. Each subport is connected to a Neutron network that will be accessible through the trunk port. The subports will also have a VID defining which VID the VM shall use to access the network connected to the subport. Example:: +---------+ | | | S1 |------------ N1 +------+ /| VID: 10 | | |+---+ / +---------+ | || |/ | VM || T |--------------------- N2 | || |\ | |+---+ \ +---------+ +------+ \| | | S2 |------------ N3 | VID: 20 | +---------+ T = Trunk port, S1-2 = Subports, N1-3 = Networks Example: :: neutron port-create --name T N2 --trunkport:type trunk Above port-create returns id of trunk port (T-id). :: neutron port-create --name S1 N1 --trunkport:parent_id <T-id> --trunkport:vid 10 --trunkport:type subport :: neutron port-create --name S2 N3 --trunkport:parent_id <T-id> --trunkport:vid 20 --trunkport:type subport Subports can have assigned IP addresses in the same way as as normal ports. The subports connected to a trunk port will inherit the MAC address from the trunk port. This enables VM to use DHCP for assignment of IP addresses on interfaces connected to subports. VM can send tagged DHCP request and the reply will contain the IP address of the matching subport. .. use :maxwidth: 240 DHCP Example: .. actdiag:: actdiag { send_dhcp -> t_dhcp -> n_dhcp -> dhcp -> rn_dhcp -> rt_dhcp -> receive_dhcp lane vm { label = "VM" send_dhcp [label = "Send DHCP on VLAN"]; receive_dhcp [label = "DHCP reveived on VLAN"]; } lane trunk { label = "Trunk port/Subport" t_dhcp [label = "Convert to network_type format"]; rt_dhcp [label = "Convert to VLAN format"]; } lane network { label = "Neutron network" n_dhcp [label = "Transmit over network"]; rn_dhcp [label = "Transmit over network"]; } lane dhcp { label = "DHCP Agent" dhcp [label = "Reply on DHCP"]; } } OVS agent will be changed to create one bridge for each trunk port. This bridge will handle the VLANs connected to the different subports on the trunk port. OVS setup:: +-----------+ | | | VM | | | +-----------+ | | +-----------+ +-------------+ | | | | | Trunkport | | br-int | | bridge | | | | | | | +-----------+ +-------------+ \ / \ / \ / +-----------+ | | | br-ex | | | +-----------+ | | Alternatives ------------ One alternative is to extend the port so that it can be connected to multiple networks directly. The main disadvantage with that is that it would change the port in such way that it affected other services in neutron that uses port information from ports connected to VMs. An example of this is the DHCP agent. Another alternative is to use a L2-gateway. One disadvantage with this is less intuitive API when it comes to address handling of addresses connected to trunk port. Current proposal is to always translate to/from VLAN for VM side. The network_type for a neutron network could be VLAN, VXLAN or other and will be translated to VLAN when send to VM. A more generic alternative could be to be able to specify what to translate to/from. It would be possible for a user to select how a network would be represented in a VM (VLAN, VXLAN or other). This would be more complex solution and also require more parameters, like IP addresses for VXLAN. All information required to setup the specified network_type needs to exist in the API parameters. Data model impact ----------------- New object: :: +-----------+ | | | TrunkPort | | | +-----------+ TrunkPort * port_id - id of port * trunk_type - type of port, either trunk or subport * parent_id - for subport port id of parent. for trunk port unset * VID - for subport VID used to reach attach network. for trunk port unset. REST API impact --------------- Trunkport extended attributes for port resource +----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+--------------+ |Attribute |Type |Access |Default |Validation/ |Description | |Name | | |Value |Conversion | | +==========+=======+=========+=========+============+==============+ |trunkport:|string |CR, all |'' |'trunk' or |type of port | |type | | | |'subport' | | +----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+--------------+ |trunkport:|string |CR, all |'' |uuid of |uuid of parent| |parent |(UUID) | | |parent | | +----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+--------------+ |trunkport:|integer|CR, all |'' |1-4094 or |color | |id | | | |'' |indicating | | | | | | |state | +----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+--------------+ Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ Performance of legacy functionality should be unaffected. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Erik.M Work Items ---------- * Security Groups support. * VXLAN support. * GRE support. * Unit test. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= None Documentation Impact ==================== Update networking API reference. References ========== None

commit_message:
Remove comment on v3 API

v3 is not a correct name now, those comments is target for v3
and no need to provide history there.
Also, v3 (v2.1) try to avoid extension now so no need to mark
a TODO for config files on extension.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I811c84aac1e702f98e4e3d94ee286d2476a0e741

subject: Add namespace oslo.db.concurrency in nova-config-generator.conf
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-29 09:24:58.000000000', 'files': ['etc/nova/nova-config-generator.conf'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/cf83eccec25d945d6278fccf6427d51df0ede2cf', 'message': 'Add namespace oslo.db.concurrency in nova-config-generator.conf

Nova uses oslo_db.concurrency.TpoolDbapiWrapper in [1], and config
option use_tpool decides to use of thread pooling for all DB API
calls[2]. We should provide this config opitons to users.

[1]https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/db/api.py#L43
[2]https://github.com/openstack/oslo.db/blob/master/oslo_db/concurrency.py#L28

Change-Id: Ic596a4db39224b5bb676765b6bcb7ac09d3aaaf4
'}]
commit_message:
Add namespace oslo.db.concurrency in nova-config-generator.conf

Nova uses oslo_db.concurrency.TpoolDbapiWrapper in [1], and config
option use_tpool decides to use of thread pooling for all DB API
calls[2]. We should provide this config opitons to users.

[1]https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/db/api.py#L43
[2]https://github.com/openstack/oslo.db/blob/master/oslo_db/concurrency.py#L28

Change-Id: Ic596a4db39224b5bb676765b6bcb7ac09d3aaaf4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/94/335394/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: namespace = oslo.db.concurrency

commit_message:
rename libvirt has_default_ephemeral

The function name suggests it returns a boolean, but it actually
returns a block device info dict. Renamed consistent with
get_root_info.

Change-Id: Ieb4ffa4cb5c2f96273e26ad0cb337c0ded2c6c30
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/66/329366/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_default_ephemeral_info(instance, disk_bus, block_device_info, mapping): default_eph = get_default_ephemeral_info(instance, disk_bus, block_device_info, mapping)
deleted_lines: def has_default_ephemeral(instance, disk_bus, block_device_info, mapping): default_eph = has_default_ephemeral(instance, disk_bus, block_device_info, mapping)

commit_message:
[install] Note that all nodes need OpenStack repositories

It is easy to ignore add the OpenStack repositories on
compute node. For this reason, we need note that.

Change-Id: I256309da46f0794ac36a3ec0607a0783e74decfb
Closes-Bug: #1586341

commit_message:
[WIP] Trick to preserve a Neutron port

In some deployments, it may be useful to preserve a port between
instance terminations.

This is a work item that was requested in the Nova-Neutron session in
Vancouver

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/YVR-nova-network

Change-Id: I6d1bde4761bf72772b6c14c8dd2ceecc4c2ebaa8
Co-Authored-By: Shilla Saebi <shilla.saebi@gmail.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/27/232627/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Tips and Tricks =============== Preserving a port and IP allocation ------------------------------------ If you are planning on terminating an instance but you'd like to preserve that instance's IP address for a new instance follow the procedures below. Be sure to follow steps 1 through 5 before terminating your instance. 1. Create a neutron port. # neutron net-list This will give you the name of the network. 2. Attach a new instance to new neutron port # neutron port-create My_Valuable_Port Take note of the port id number of the newly created port. It will be used in our next command that boots and attaches a new instance to the IP address. # nova --os-region-name ndc_as_a boot --flavor m1.tiny --image <id> --security_group <name> --nic port-id=<port id number> PortTest1 3. Verify # neutron port-show <port id number> # nova show <instance UUID> 4. Detach the port from the instance (note: if you get an error similar to "The resource could not be found", try this command again without the --binding:host_id option) #neutron port-update <port id number> --device_id " " --device_owner " " 5. Verify that the neutron port is successfully detached from the instance # nova show <instance UUID> 6. You are now free to terminate your instance. 7. You can boot a new instance and attach it to your existing neutron port (IP address). Repeat step 2. Note: the last argument of the command gives the instance its name.

commit_message:
Add a trust notifier task

This adds the ability to send keystone authentified notifications using
trusts. To do so, you specify the posted URL with the "trust+" prefix,
and Zaqar will create and store a trust when subscribing to a queue, if
the trust not provided in the subscription options

It also add a capability to the webhook task to be able to send more
structured data in the notification, allowing to include the Zaqar
message in the data.

blueprint mistral-notifications
DocImpact
Change-Id: I12b9c1b34cdd220fcf1bdc2720043d4a8f75dc85

commit_message:
Replace unicode with six.text_type

The Unicode type is 'unicode' in Python 2 and 'str' on Python 3.
This patch replaces unicode with six.text_type to make Nova
compatible with Python 2 and Python 3.

Blueprint nova-python3

Change-Id: I9e883798129ee3ea692e63cf0466b9cfd400a01d

commit_message:
Correct reraising of exception

When an exception was caught and rethrown, it should call 'raise'
without any arguments because it shows the place where an exception
occured initially instead of place where the exception re-raised.

Change-Id: I66a3ed74faa103b156c9eda0e944b23c0a75df58

commit_message:
Allow for Nova to use os-brick from git

This option to install os-brick from git was only added
into lib/cinder previously. When testing all-in-one nodes
this worked fine, but if you have multi-node setups with
compute nodes that don't install any c-* services we
only get packaged os-brick. With this change non-cinder
nodes can now test against unreleased os-bricks.

Change-Id: Ibb7423d243d57852dada0b6298463bbdfc6dc63c

commit_message:
Added a new specification for Tenant domainID for Designate Sink

Change-Id: I57550fddc44a4503615ef31e712771bdd18c9f2e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate-specs refs/changes/81/272081/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================================== Tenant DomainID for Designate-Sink ==================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/designate/+spec/tenant-domainid-for-designate-sink Right now Designate Sink creates DNS records in a predefined domain which is common for all the tenants. Designate should have this feature where records are created in tenant domains so that tenants can make changes to the records created by Designate Sink if required. Problem description =================== Desigante Sink create DNS A records in a predefined domain. Tenant doesn't have access to these records and can never access them even if he needs to update them. Proposed change =============== Right now designate-sink handlers in designate.conf has hard coded domainID. We can change this to %(domainid) so that base.py can look for a default domainId for the tenant and use that domainID to publish the records into the tenants domain. Sink Changes --------------- nova.py and neutron.py needs to be updated so that tenant's default domain for sink is considered. If there is no default domain for the tenant then consider the zone/domainID. If tenant has only one domain then that will be the default domain of the tenant. base.py needs to be updated so that new params in the config file can be accomodated. API Changes ----------- API calls related direclty to domain will have an impact. POST /domains .. code-block:: http Request ------- POST /domains HTTP/1.1 Host: example.com Accept: application/json Content-Type: application/json { "name": "domain1.com.", "ttl": 3600, "email": "nsadmin@example.org", "default" : false } Response -------- HTTP/1.1 200 OK Vary: Accept Content-Type: application/json { "id": "89acac79-38e7-497d-807c-a011e1310438", "name": "domain1.com.", "ttl": 3600, "serial": 1351800588, "email": "nsadmin@example.org", "created_at": "2012-11-01T20:09:48.094457", "updated_at": null, "description": null, "default" : false } GET /domains/(uuid: id) .. code-block:: http Example request: GET /domains/09494b72-b65b-4297-9efb-187f65a0553e HTTP/1.1 Host: example.com Accept: application/json Example response: HTTP/1.1 200 OK Vary: Accept Content-Type: application/json { "id": "09494b72-b65b-4297-9efb-187f65a0553e", "name": "domain1.com.", "ttl": 3600, "serial": 1351800668, "email": "nsadmin@example.org", "created_at": "2012-11-01T20:11:08.000000", "updated_at": null, "description": null, "default": true } PUT /domains/(uuid:id) GET /domains Storage Chages -------------- Update domain/zone storage/impl_sqlalchemy/tables.py Alternatives ------------ Alternatively domainID in designate.conf can be hard coded to zone/domainID so that all records created by designate-sink endup in one common domain. Implementation ============== Domain table needs to have an extra column for flaging the domain as default domain. sink module in desginate.conf will have few more parameters like: 1. defaultdomainid (either hardcoded or left blank, default being blank) 2. tenantspecificdomain (true/false default to false) 2. fallbacktodefaultdomain (true/false default to true. Only applicable if tenantspecificdomain is set to true) Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: ramsateesh-talari Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: Mataka-1 Work Items ---------- Update Doamin Table Update Domain in storage Update API for domains --POST --PUT --GET Update nova.py Update neutron.py Update base.py

commit_message:
Add 'loadbalancer', 'listener' help info for quota-update

In lbaas v2, the 'vip' will not exist, and the 'loadbalancer', 'listener'
are added to resources, we should add them into help information.

Change-Id: I3a26272b9eff8c1d20136ff3f2b877e64171bcf2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-neutronclient refs/changes/36/334436/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

* PCI-DSS 8.1.4: Remove/disable inactive user accounts within 90 days.

The number of inactive days is configurable.

Partially-implements: blueprint pci-dss

Change-Id: Ief0572de014f4719e001dfd558f501c99a8850dd
'}]
commit_message:
PCI-DSS Disable inactive users requirements

This patch satisfies the following PCI-DSS disable inactive user
requirements:

* PCI-DSS 8.1.4: Remove/disable inactive user accounts within 90 days.

The number of inactive days is configurable.

Partially-implements: blueprint pci-dss

Change-Id: Ief0572de014f4719e001dfd558f501c99a8850dd

commit_message:
Fix argument order for assertEqual to (expected, observed)

assertEqual expects that the arguments provided to it should be
(expected, observed). If a particluar order is kept as a convention,
then it helps to provide a cleaner message to the developer if Unit
Tests fail. The following patch fixes this issue.

TrivialFix
Closes-Bug: #1259292

Change-Id: I03c414a763b2d51210aaec362405912f29850e36

Add Python 3.5 classifier and venv

Python 3.5 in the classifier. This patch also adds the convenience
py35 venv.

commit_message:
Bump to Nova v2.1

1.What is the problem:
The nova team has decided to remove nova v2 API code completely.
And the patch have been merged.

Refer to https://review.openstack.org/#/c/311653/

2.What is the solution to the problem:
To fix the issue, we should bump to use v2.1 ASAP.

3.What is the purpose of this patch set:
The v2.1 API has been used as the default API since Liberty and legacy
v2 API has been marked as deprecated. Based on this, we bump to use
v2.1 ASAP for better development of the Tricircle.

Change-Id: I375a6509cf80613804f3fff19054d699dc5d8a1b

commit_message:
Add multiple CPU architecture support spec

Add a spec outlining requirements, work items, and testing needed to
enable OpenStack-Ansible to support deployments with nodes from
multiple CPU architectures, starting with ppc64el

Change-Id: Ie2851fc71cf7a79b347fa1cfee6b574037b81fa8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-specs refs/changes/37/329637/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Multiple CPU Architecture Support ################################# :date: 2016-06-14 12:00 :tags: openstack, ansible, power The purpose of this spec is to enable OpenStack-Ansible to deploy OpenStack in clouds with multiple CPU architectures across the nodes to be deployed. Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/openstack-ansible/+spec/example The purpose of this spec is to add support for multiple CPU architectures to OpenStack Ansible. With the introduction of OpenStack services running on other architectures such as PPC64LE, OpenStack-Ansible needs to be extended to support environments where a mixed environment of CPU architectures exists. Problem description =================== OpenStack-Ansible was initially built to support deployments to a single architecture, primarily x86. With the extension of OpenStack and OpenStack-Ansible support to other platforms such as POWER, support for deployments running a combination of different CPU architectures is needed. For each deployment, OpenStack-Ansible creates and builds an 'repo' containing necessary artifacts for the OpenStack deployment. This repo holds components such as pip wheels, virtualenvs, and source trees for the different services to be deployed. For each deployment a single 'master' repo is designated where artifacts are built, then synchronized out to the rest of the slaves. This creates problems in a multi-architecture deployment for nodes where the repo master's CPU architecture is different than the architecture of other nodes. For example, deployment of a KVM on POWER compute node will fail when the artifacts were built on an x86 repo master used for the control plane. Proposed change =============== Update OpenStack-Ansible and necessary roles to support building and deploying with multiple CPU architectures. This includes changes to: * Detect and store the CPU architectures used across all hosts * Support a 'repo master' for each CPU architecture in the deployment * Support building copies of all artifacts on each repo master, then copying to all other masters for synchronization out to slaves. * Support tagging built artifacts with their CPU architecture where needed * Maintain backwards compatibility with existing single-architecture deployments by linking a non-tagged version of artifacts to the primary tagged architecture versions * Ensure pre-built binaries used during installation (apt packages, etc) exist or are made available for the supported CPU architectures (x86, ppc64el Alternatives ------------ * Potential Alternative - Cross compiling artifacts (under investigation) * Support only single-architecture OpenStack-Ansible deployments. This is harmful to deployers by limiting the potential integration of servers from other architectures into new and existing OpenStack-Ansible deployments Playbook/Role impact -------------------- There will be impact to the repo playbooks to handle building and synchronizing across multiple architectures. There will also be minor impact to each role to support building and tagging artifacts with the required architecture information. Upgrade impact -------------- This change should be made transparent to existing environments by linking a copy of non-tagged build artifacts where needed. Security impact --------------- N/A Performance impact ------------------ Both repo build and synchronization operations will take longer to complete proportionate to the number of CPU architectures being deployed. * Repo builds can occur in parallel across each CPU architecture, minimizing the build-time performance impact * Synchronizations will take longer and require more bandwidth to transfer when there are multiple architectures due to the increased number of artifacts being built. End user impact --------------- No end user impact is expected. Deployer impact --------------- Deployers will now be able to create deployments with servers with servers of multiple CPU architectures included. No other deployer impact is expected as the detection of multiple architectures, deploy of the required number of repo masters for each architecture, and build of artifacts for each architecture should happen dynamically. Developer impact ---------------- Developer impact will be minor. Developers will now be able to develop for and test deployments across multiple CPU architectures. It also enables development of roles specific to other CPU architectures in the future, such as ARM. Dependencies ------------ N/A Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: ashana@us.ibm.com/ashana Other contributors: adreznec@us.ibm.com/adreznec thorst@us.ibm.com/thorst Work items ---------- * Add a repo discovery tasks to detect and store facts on the CPU architectures used across all hosts, and assign a master for each architecture * Modify the repo-server playbook to support deploying the correct number of clustered repo containers per-CPU architecture * Modify the repo-build playbook to tag the repo masters with their corresponding CPU architecture * Update the repo synchronization tasks to support multiple masters synchronizing every master's artifacts out to each slave * Create a link from untagged artifacts to the artifacts built for the first/primary CPU architecture to maintain backwards compatibility for existing single-architecture deployments. * Ensure binary packages are available on all package mirrors/locations for ppc64el in addition to i386/amd64. * More TBD Testing ======= TBD... will probably require a third-party CI job? Documentation impact ==================== Documentation covering how to configure multi-arch support will be added to the user guide. References ========== * https://github.com/openstack/openstack-ansible-specs/blob/master/specs/newton/powervm-virt-driver.rst

commit_message:
Add new flag migrate process finishing.

For qa test it is necessary to determine when migration process finished.
For this purposes /not_ready was used. But it has some disadvantages, it
covers not whole migration process. And there was possibility to mistake.
So was added new  flag which appears after finishing of migration. Old
was left because of old tests. Both of them are used only for testing
propouses and don't affect migration process.

Partial-Bug: #1576276
Change-Id: I49b62dc743111cb4c41489c528e48f8d56c2f9df

Typically set via parameter_defaults in the resource registry. type: json MysqlVirtualIPUri: type: string default: '' GnocchiBackend: default: file description: The short name of the Gnocchi backend to use. Should be one of swift, rbd, or file type: string constraints: - allowed_values: ['swift', 'file', 'rbd'] GnocchiIndexerBackend: default: 'mysql' description: The short name of the Gnocchi indexer backend to use. type: string GnocchiPassword: description: The password for the gnocchi service and db account. type: string hidden: true outputs: role_data: description: Role data for the Gnocchi role. value: config_settings: gnocchi_dsn: list_join: - '' - - 'mysql+pymysql://gnocchi:' - {get_param: GnocchiPassword} - '@' - {get_param: MysqlVirtualIPUri} - '/gnocchi' gnocchi_backend: {get_input: GnocchiBackend} gnocchi_indexer_backend: {get_input: GnocchiIndexerBackend} gnocchi_mysql_conn_string: {get_input: gnocchi_dsn} gnocchi::debug: {get_input: debug} gnocchi::wsgi::apache::ssl: false gnocchi::api::service_name: 'httpd' gnocchi::api::keystone_password: {get_input: gnocchi_password} gnocchi::db::mysql::password: {get_input: gnocchi_password} gnocchi::storage::swift::swift_key: {get_input: gnocchi_password} gnocchi::keystone::auth::password: {get_input: gnocchi_password } tripleo::profile::base::gnocchi::gnocchi_database_connection: {get_input: gnocchi_mysql_conn_string} step_config: | include ::tripleo::profile::base::gnocchi

commit_message:
Add Python 3.5 classifier and venv

Now that there is a passing gate job, we can claim support for
Python 3.5 in the classifier. This patch also adds the convenience
py35 venv.

Change-Id: I712c4e32e4db3e5ef826c69a11b8c3338753906f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.policy refs/changes/77/340777/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: envlist = py35,py34,py27,pep8,docs

commit_message:
Fix Cloud Server image/flavor combination validation

Custom Cloud Server images do not have the 'flavor_classes' key in
their metadata, so try to get it from the base image.  If
'flavor_classes' is empty or does not exist, skip image/flavor
validation.

Closes-Bug: #1570087
Change-Id: I44fd02c689ba0c06ba571d04e9baf0eb0ce035ff
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/58/306058/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: mock_image.__iter__ = mock.Mock(return_value=iter([])) mock_image.__iter__ = mock.Mock(return_value=iter([])) mock_image.__iter__ = mock.Mock(return_value=iter([])) def test_validate_image_flavor_empty_metadata(self, mock_client, mock_plugin): server = cloud_server.CloudServer("test", self.rsrcdef, self.mockstack) mock_image = mock.Mock(size=1, status='ACTIVE', min_ram=2, min_disk=2) mock_image.get.return_value = "" mock_image.__iter__ = mock.Mock(return_value=iter([])) mock_flavor = mock.Mock(ram=4, disk=4) mock_flavor.to_dict.return_value = { 'OS-FLV-WITH-EXT-SPECS:extra_specs': { 'flavor_classes': '', }, } mock_plugin().get_flavor.return_value = mock_flavor mock_plugin().get_image.return_value = mock_image self.assertIsNone(server.validate()) def test_validate_image_flavor_no_metadata(self, mock_client, mock_plugin): server = cloud_server.CloudServer("test", self.rsrcdef, self.mockstack) mock_image = mock.Mock(size=1, status='ACTIVE', min_ram=2, min_disk=2) mock_image.get.return_value = None mock_image.__iter__ = mock.Mock(return_value=iter([])) mock_flavor = mock.Mock(ram=4, disk=4) mock_flavor.to_dict.return_value = {} mock_plugin().get_flavor.return_value = mock_flavor mock_plugin().get_image.return_value = mock_image self.assertIsNone(server.validate()) def test_validate_image_flavor_not_base(self, mock_client, mock_plugin): server = cloud_server.CloudServer("test", self.rsrcdef, self.mockstack) mock_image = mock.Mock(size=1, status='ACTIVE', min_ram=2, min_disk=2) mock_image.get.return_value = None mock_image.__iter__ = mock.Mock(return_value=iter( ['base_image_ref'])) mock_image.__getitem__ = mock.Mock(return_value='1234') mock_base_image = mock.Mock(size=1, status='ACTIVE', min_ram=2, min_disk=2) mock_base_image.get.return_value = None mock_base_image.__iter__ = mock.Mock(return_value=iter([])) mock_flavor = mock.Mock(ram=4, disk=4) commit_message:
Fix Neutron local_ip fallback

A fallback was added in I954a46443b5434b589226c4999e71bd6ba6a5c0b to
use ansible_ssh_host when no overlay network exists.

However, when the above change is used against hosts that do not use
either an overlay network or an interface named br-mgmt, then the play
will fail with:
One or more undefined variables: 'dict object' has no attribute u'ansible_br_mgmt'

This fixes the change to use the ansible_default_ipv4['interface']
instead of hard-coding br-mgmt.

Change-Id: I21767690c8dd76a4513d8f3d0ac2dfffbd10a026
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/55/338255/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: _local_ip: "{{ hostvars[inventory_hostname]['ansible_' + _overlay_network.bridge|default(ansible_default_ipv4['interface'])|replace('-', '_')]['ipv4']['address']|default(ansible_ssh_host) }}"

commit_message:
Put correct Etag and Accept-Ranges in EC 304 and 416 responses

When using an EC policy, 304 responses to conditional GETs
are missing the Accept-Ranges header and have the wrong ETag
value. 412 responses also have the wrong etag.

416 responses to ranged GETs also have the wrong ETag.

This patch ensures behaviour with EC policy is consistent
with replication policy:

  - 304 and 416 responses have correct etag and Accept-Ranges
  - 412 responses have correct Etag but no Accept-Ranges

Co-Authored-By: Mahati Chamarthy <mahati.chamarthy@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Thiago da Silva <thiago@redhat.com>

Cherry-picked from commit 12dd408823df158359e99fb01716f2059140c5c9

Closes-Bug: #1496234
Closes-Bug: #1558197
Closes-Bug: #1558193
Change-Id: Ic21317b9e4f632f0751133a3383eb5487379e11f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/92/324392/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Properly updates the SG rules when SG is changed

When a port's security group is changed, the neutron-hyperv-agent
receives a port_update notification. Next, the agent will call the
HyperVSecurityGroupsDriver's prepare_port_filter, in order to process
the new security group.

prepare_port_filter does not remove any old rules from the port.
update_port_filter should called instead, as it removes old rules.

Removes 'security_group_id' and 'remote_group_id' from security
group rules, as they make checking rule equality harder, and they
are not used in applying the rules.

Closes-Bug: #1586354

Change-Id: I1c6f4bd08020ae8ae2dd6ac665a3ddb602b518c4
(cherry picked from commit 9233449d97a9ccd2c6bd008b8c7d035174833d82)

commit_message:
Add testing of instance host changes during deletes

In the compute API, we have logic that handles races where the
instance host changes while we're trying to delete the instance.
The logic catches host change exceptions and refreshes the instance,
in order to refresh the instance.host. Then, subsequent delete
attempts are made following the refresh.

This adds tests for the code paths where the instance.host changes
while we are deleting the instance.

Change-Id: I5231f0790bce3fac429ee50142ab81e0ba720c20
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/64/328564/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch('nova.objects.BlockDeviceMappingList.get_by_instance_uuid') @mock.patch('nova.objects.Instance.save') @mock.patch('nova.compute.api.API._create_reservations') @mock.patch('nova.compute.utils.notify_about_instance_usage') @mock.patch('nova.objects.Instance.destroy') @mock.patch('nova.objects.Instance.refresh') @mock.patch('nova.compute.api.API._local_delete') @mock.patch('nova.compute.api.API._record_action_start') def test_delete_host_changed_scheduled( self, mock_record, mock_local_del, mock_refresh, mock_destroy, mock_notify, mock_create_res, mock_save, mock_get_bdms): """Test when an instance is scheduled during a local delete. If we get an ObjectActionError from instance.destroy(), it means that the instance host has changed under us. Verify we continue on to do a non-local delete. This scenario is an unscheduled instance becoming scheduled at the same time local delete is attempted. """ mock_destroy.side_effect = exception.ObjectActionError( action='destroy', reason='host changed') instance = self._create_instance_obj(params=dict(host=None)) with mock.patch.object(self.compute_api.compute_rpcapi, 'terminate_instance') as mock_terminate: self.compute_api.delete(self.context, instance) # If in the api cell, it immediately casts to the child cell if self.cell_type != 'api': # instance destroy attempted mock_destroy.assert_called_once_with() # instance host changed, refresh host mock_refresh.assert_called_once_with() # instance has host, _local_delete should not be called mock_local_del.assert_not_called() # non-local delete attempted mock_terminate.assert_called_once_with( self.context, instance, mock_get_bdms.return_value, reservations=mock_create_res.return_value.reservations, delete_type='delete') else: mock_terminate.assert_called_once_with(self.context, instance, mock_get_bdms.return_value, reservations=None, delete_type='delete') @mock.patch('nova.objects.BlockDeviceMappingList.get_by_instance_uuid') @mock.patch('nova.image.api.API.delete') @mock.patch('nova.objects.Instance.save') @mock.patch('nova.compute.api.API._create_reservations') @mock.patch('nova.compute.utils.notify_about_instance_usage') @mock.patch('nova.objects.Instance.destroy') @mock.patch('nova.objects.Instance.refresh') @mock.patch('nova.compute.api.API._local_delete') @mock.patch('nova.compute.api.API._record_action_start') def test_delete_host_changed_unshelved( self, mock_record, mock_local_del, mock_refresh, mock_destroy, mock_notify, mock_create_res, mock_save, mock_image, mock_get_bdms): """Test when an instance is unshelved during a local delete. If we get an ObjectActionError from instance.destroy(), it means that the instance host has changed under us. Verify we continue on to do a non-local delete. This scenario is a shelved offloaded instance becoming unshelved at the same time local delete is attempted. """ # _local_delete does instance.destroy() in it mock_local_del.side_effect = exception.ObjectActionError( action='destroy', reason='host changed') instance = self._create_instance_obj( params=dict(host=None, vm_state=vm_states.SHELVED_OFFLOADED)) with mock.patch.object(self.compute_api.compute_rpcapi, 'terminate_instance') as mock_terminate: self.compute_api.delete(self.context, instance) # If in the api cell, it immediately casts to the child cell if self.cell_type != 'api': # instance destroy should not be attempted without extra # cleanup if the instance has been scheduled before in the past mock_destroy.assert_not_called() # attempt local delete with volume/network/etc cleanup mock_local_del.assert_called_once_with(self.context, instance, mock_get_bdms.return_value, 'delete', self.compute_api._do_delete) # local delete host changed, refresh host mock_refresh.assert_called_once_with() # non-local delete attempted mock_terminate.assert_called_once_with( self.context, instance, mock_get_bdms.return_value, reservations=mock_create_res.return_value.reservations, delete_type='delete') else: mock_terminate.assert_called_once_with(self.context, instance, mock_get_bdms.return_value, reservations=None, delete_type='delete')

subject: Local delete instances in error state if host not set
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-08 01:58:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/aefda3f94be1a1d8868b09e8a15e38ae668c1804', 'message': "Local delete instances in error state if host not set

Commit 5ce74fa06c0e7a70fdc927b2c1f364af83f7de1d fixed a bug where
volumes weren't being detached when deleting instances in error
state. The patch made the wrong assumption that an instance in
error state will have no host set because of the exception
handling on the compute host. This isn't necessarily true, as
we have a tempest test that uses reset-state to put an instance
into error state before deleting it. In this case, since the
instance has a host set, we should check the service up/down
status and do a local or non-local delete depending on the status.

This addresses the issue by changing the logic for whether to
check host up/down to simply look if instance.host is None instead
of basing it on the vm_state. It also changes the variable naming
to avoid double negatives.

Closes-Bug: #1600031

Change-Id: I0eaeea21c92a171fa2e0b5c9321a8637ffc02ad5

commit_message:
Local delete instances in error state if host not set

Commit 5ce74fa06c0e7a70fdc927b2c1f364af83f7de1d fixed a bug where
volumes weren't being detached when deleting instances in error
state. The patch made the wrong assumption that an instance in
error state will have no host set because of the exception
handling on the compute host. This isn't necessarily true, as
we have a tempest test that uses reset-state to put an instance
into error state before deleting it. In this case, since the
instance has a host set, we should check the service up/down
status and do a local or non-local delete depending on the status.

This addresses the issue by changing the logic for whether to
check host up/down to simply look if instance.host is None instead
of basing it on the vm_state. It also changes the variable naming
to avoid double negatives.

Closes-Bug: #1600031
Related-Bug: #1404867

Change-Id: I0eaeea21c92a171fa2e0b5c9321a8637ffc02ad5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/07/339307/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(melwitt): We expect instances in certain states to possibly # have no host set, yet have resources on a compute host. If this # is the case, we want to try to clean up their resources. # Otherwse, we can destroy the instance here and return. expect_instance_host = self._expect_host(instance) if not instance.host and expect_instance_host: if instance.host is not None: def _expect_host(self, instance): # NOTE(melwitt): It is possible for instances in ERROR state to have # their host and node set to None as part of exception handling. if instance.vm_state in (vm_states.SHELVED_OFFLOADED, vm_states.ERROR): return False return True
deleted_lines: # NOTE(melwitt): We expect instances in certain states to have no # host set but also have resources on a compute host. If this is # the case, we want to try to clean up their resources. Otherwse, # we can destroy the instance here and return. expect_no_instance_host = self._expect_no_host(instance) if not instance.host and not expect_no_instance_host: if not expect_no_instance_host: # NOTE(melwitt): We expect this if instance.host has been # set to None by the compute host during a claim abort # and we pick it up in the instance.refresh() def _expect_no_host(self, instance): # NOTE(melwitt): Instances in ERROR state have their host and node # set to None as part of exception handling. if instance.vm_state in (vm_states.SHELVED_OFFLOADED, vm_states.ERROR): return True return False

commit_message:
Adds flavor to fake_instance_obj

If there is no flavor set, it will try to fetch it from database,
which would fail. This is needed for future unit tests.

Change-Id: I19e91a2f4b932c59b8ae6e9f0df435498b4b5521

commit_message:
Added git package to the utility container

This package is needed on utility containers to allow git clones
from the repo server and/or other locations. Without this package
Tempest role can not execute because the role assumes git is already
available within an environment where it is to be executed.

Its worth noting that this works fine in Ubuntu 14.04 because of the
heavy nature of the base container image while in Ubuntu 16.04 the
container images are far more minimal.

Change-Id: I63f051cc7fa6045eed8332713de3eea241f17504
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/94/340594/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add Amulet functional tests

Add amulet tests; these are currently a copy of the
tests from the openvswitch-odl charm but do provide
some base level of functional verification of the
charm.

Enable test targets for currently supported releases
of OpenStack and Ubuntu.

Change-Id: I8486e30297b7d5e4bc9649ef94a6e447315bfbd8

commit_message:
Remove the conditional check for topology

The 'topology' is already been checked in both
    octavia.controller.worker.flows.load_balancer_flows.get_create_load_balancer_flow
and
    octavia.controller.worker.flows.load_balancer_flows.get_post_lb_amp_association_flow

Change-Id: Id6f9ac2a2b880542392581113bcc76550ae41f62
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/72/334772/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: store[constants.UPDATE_DICT] = {constants.LOADBALANCER_TOPOLOGY: topology}
deleted_lines: if topology == constants.TOPOLOGY_SINGLE: store[constants.UPDATE_DICT] = {constants.LOADBALANCER_TOPOLOGY: constants.TOPOLOGY_SINGLE} elif topology == constants.TOPOLOGY_ACTIVE_STANDBY: store[constants.UPDATE_DICT] = {constants.LOADBALANCER_TOPOLOGY: constants.TOPOLOGY_ACTIVE_STANDBY} # blogan and sbalukoff asked to remove the else check here # as it is also checked later in the flow create code

commit_message:
Update ensurability fixtures

The commit applies only to stable/mitaka branch as in master
changes in puppets are being made, which makes the list of
task and/or affected resources different from what is in the
released version.

Change-Id: Iad2145535c6328dc644698902c75f548f3440509
Closes-Bug: #1586974

commit_message:
Add force_set_boot to IpmiNode

- Now chassis_set_boot is called only if force_set_boot is set to True
  Note: force_set_boot is True by default
- Use IpmiNode.boot parameter in chassis_set_boot instead of
  hardcoded 'pxe' string
- Removed redundant IpmiNode.create and erase methods
- Added wait for power off in the missing places
- Added call for super methods in the missing places
- Added unit test for IpmiNode

Closes-Bug: #1588279
Change-Id: I2c097d1dfaef107ff328749b9466a2096022e814

added_lines: # Copyright 2016 Mirantis, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import mock from devops.models import Environment from django.test import TestCase class TestIpmiNode(TestCase): def patch(self, *args, **kwargs): patcher = mock.patch(*args, **kwargs) m = patcher.start() self.addCleanup(patcher.stop) return m def setUp(self): super(TestIpmiNode, self).setUp() # Create Environment self.ipmiclient_mock = self.patch( 'devops.driver.baremetal.ipmi_driver.IpmiClient', autospec=True) self.ipmiclient = self.ipmiclient_mock.return_value self.wait_mock = self.patch( 'devops.driver.baremetal.ipmi_driver.wait') self.env = Environment.create('test_env') self.group = self.env.add_group( group_name='test_group', driver_name='devops.driver.baremetal', ) self.ap = self.env.add_address_pool( name='test_ap', net='172.0.0.0/16:24', tag=0, ip_reserved=dict(l2_network_device=1), ) self.net_pool = self.group.add_network_pool( name='fuelweb_admin', address_pool_name='test_ap', ) self.l2_net_dev = self.group.add_l2_network_device( name='test_l2_net_dev', address_pool='test_ap', ) self.node = self.group.add_node( name='test_node', role='default', boot='pxe', force_set_boot=True, ipmi_user='user1', ipmi_password='pass1', ipmi_previlegies='OPERATOR', ipmi_host='ipmi-1.hostaddress.net', ipmi_lan_interface='lanplus', ipmi_port=623, ) def test_define(self): self.node.define() def test_is_active(self): self.ipmiclient.power_status.return_value = 0 assert self.node.is_active() def test_is_active_false(self): self.ipmiclient.power_status.return_value = 1 assert self.node.is_active() is False def test_exists(self): self.ipmiclient.check_remote_host.return_value = True assert self.node.exists() self.ipmiclient.check_remote_host.assert_called_once_with() def test_start(self): self.ipmiclient.power_status.return_value = 1 self.node.start() self.ipmiclient.assert_has_calls(( mock.call.chassis_set_boot('pxe'), mock.call.power_status(), mock.call.power_on(), )) def test_restart(self): self.ipmiclient.power_status.return_value = 0 self.node.start() self.ipmiclient.assert_has_calls(( mock.call.chassis_set_boot('pxe'), mock.call.power_status(), mock.call.power_reset(), )) self.wait_mock.assert_called_once_with( self.node.is_active, timeout=60, timeout_msg="Node test_node / ipmi-1.hostaddress.net wasn't " "started in 60 sec") def test_destroy(self): self.ipmiclient.power_status.return_value = 0 self.node.destroy() self.ipmiclient.power_off.assert_called_once_with() assert self.wait_mock.called def test_remove(self): self.ipmiclient.power_status.return_value = 0 self.node.remove() self.ipmiclient.assert_has_calls(( mock.call.power_status(), mock.call.power_off(), )) assert self.wait_mock.called def test_reset(self): self.node.reset() self.ipmiclient.power_reset.assert_called_once_with() def test_reboot(self): self.node.reboot() self.ipmiclient.power_reset.assert_called_once_with() def test_shutdown(self): self.node.shutdown() self.ipmiclient.power_off.assert_called_once_with() assert self.wait_mock.called

commit_message:
Fixed running tox while stacked

Tox tests for py27 and py34 would fail various numbers of tests
when tox was run multiple times without a clean stack. This patch
tracked down the missing mocks for the various tests and put them
into place. Now running tox should pass green no matter if the
user has a running stack or does not have a running stack.

Change-Id: I0b11c83ec7ccfdc57790213d415b30d52fd55a61
Closes-Bug: 1599330

subject: Revert "Switch away from the default IP range used by tripleo"
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-12 19:29:07.000000000', 'files': ['toci_instack_ovb.sh', 'toci_instack.sh', 'scripts/deploy.sh', 'toci_gate_test.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci/commit/decc80b4a6c1342643015742c4db41d368bc7947', 'message': 'Revert "Switch away from the default IP range used by tripleo"

This broke the nonha job, which runs SSL on the overcloud and
relies on having a predictable IP for the public VIP.  Since
that jobs doesn't do net-iso, it uses the provisioning address
as the VIP.

We also can't just sed the template because the certificate
has to match, so let's just revert this for now and figure out
a safe way to do it once CI is unblocked.

This reverts commit 2ffce235be4843bfa58dafb03c24b11b65f0c0e1.

Change-Id: I9bf6e832c4d914ac5d7dcef1070e1ca894b2e2b5
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Switch away from the default IP range used by tripleo"

This broke the nonha job, which runs SSL on the overcloud and
relies on having a predictable IP for the public VIP.  Since
that jobs doesn't do net-iso, it uses the provisioning address
as the VIP.

We also can't just sed the template because the certificate
has to match, so let's just revert this for now and figure out
a safe way to do it once CI is unblocked.

This reverts commit 2ffce235be4843bfa58dafb03c24b11b65f0c0e1.

Change-Id: I9bf6e832c4d914ac5d7dcef1070e1ca894b2e2b5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci refs/changes/49/341149/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Remove vim headers

We don't need vim settings in each source file:

comment - # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4

It can be set in user's vimrc.

Change-Id: I205123ae076cf5801f24992cb4897ba2a37bd4b5
Partial-Bug: #1229324

commit_message:
Add gateway in network_info and share network API

Get gateway information from network plugin and put it into network_info.
It is required by EMC Unity storage to create a interface.

APIImpact
DocImpact

Change-Id: I8614b8686af7fa5764b49e8e3cb4a4855dc3a5f4
Implements: blueprint add-gateway-info

commit_message:
implement hashing data for plugins configs

exposing hash of plugin configs is needed to correctly
avoid loading too many configs data in horizon for plugins.

Change-Id: I68c783ad3591af8d007062774a5b7e93c75f3bf8
Related-bug: 1430112
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/16/331216/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_serialization import jsonutils as json _plugin_data_hashes = None def get_static_version_info(self, version): info = {} configs = self.get_all_configs(version) info['configs'] = [c.dict for c in configs] processes = self.get_node_processes(version) info['node_processes'] = processes required_image_tags = self.get_required_image_tags(version) info['required_image_tags'] = required_image_tags return info def invalidate_plugin_data_hashes(self): self._plugin_data_hashes = None def get_plugin_data_hashes(self): if self._plugin_data_hashes: return self._plugin_data_hashes data = {} for version in self.get_versions(): info = self.get_static_version_info(version) hash_data = hash(json.dumps(info)) data[version] = hash_data self._plugin_data_hashes = data return self._plugin_data_hashes res['data_hashes_by_version'] = self.get_plugin_data_hashes()
